topics.title: PM behaviors that annoy engineers most
topics.summary: Camille lists common PM pitfalls: hoarding credit, dismissing technical details, playing telephone between stakeholders and engineers, and hoarding product ideas. She explains why each behavior erodes trust and can lead to worse engineering outcomes.

topics.title: How PMs can involve engineers in ideation
topics.summary: They discuss tactics for bringing engineers into the creative loop without PMs feeling threatened. Camille emphasizes relationship-building, listening to ideas, and helping engineers appreciate the full scope of the product role.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for DX and CommandBar (Command AI).

topics.title: Why major rewrites are usually a trap
topics.summary: Camille explains why full rewrites often fail: migration time is massively underestimated, legacy logic is hard to replicate, and teams still must support the old system. She recommends staged evolutions and uplifting well-contained components instead.

topics.title: Engineering leaders staying technical while managing
topics.summary: Camille advises leaders to build deep technical mastery before going hands-off, then stay credible by asking good questions, listening closely, and surrounding themselves with strong technical people. They discuss ways to keep up via networks, chats, and reading.

topics.title: Framework fads and when tech choices don’t scale
topics.summary: They compare “simple stacks” (PHP/jQuery) vs constantly chasing new frameworks, and how what works for a solo builder may not work for teams. Camille flags GraphQL as an example where teams should be clear on the problem it solves.

topics.title: When to move from IC to management
topics.summary: Camille suggests waiting until technical skill is “in your bones,” offering a rough 10-year mastery heuristic (adjusted for earlier coding experience). She notes this is especially important for underrepresented engineers who may face skepticism about technical ability.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda and how it’s used for planning and workflows.

topics.title: What surprises new managers about the job
topics.summary: Camille describes the shock of losing control of your time and realizing management is a service role, not command-and-control authority. They discuss why some people return to IC roles and differences between managing engineers vs PMs.

topics.title: Why too many one-on-ones don’t scale
topics.summary: Camille distinguishes essential 1:1s (manager/direct reports) from excessive stakeholder and peer 1:1s that don’t scale and can hide misalignment. She argues for respecting time, using group forums when appropriate, and avoiding purposeless meetings.

topics.title: Work culture: focus over overwork
topics.summary: Camille argues that overwork can be a way to avoid prioritization, and that strong cultures push teams to focus on what matters most. She frames this as regularly testing assumptions about what’s truly important rather than defaulting to long hours.
